sentences.sentence: The foreign policy journey of Anthony Albanese from an opponent of George W. Bush's invasion of Iraq to a true believer in the US alliance is outlined on today's features pages by Sydney University professor of history James Curran and Elena Collinson of the Australia-China Institute.

Early this century, the young firebrand from Labor's inner-city social activist wing held fashionable "progressive" opinions, including endorsing Naomi Klein-style anti-globalisation critiques of the "school of international order that sees no role for the nation state in trade or investment policies".

Two decades on, the man who occupies The Lodge, and will represent Australia on the world stage during the next fortnight of back-to-back-to-back international summitry, supports maintaining and strengthening the critical security partnership with America.

That positions Mr Albanese squarely in the bipartisan strategic consensus and the mainstream of Labor politics alongside its most electorally successful leader and ardent US alliance supporter, Bob Hawke.

Foreign policy has not been Mr Albanese's political passion; hence he has come to office with relatively little "anti-US forces" baggage to declare.Yet, despite being inexperienced in international affairs, Mr Albanese so far has shown a safe pair of hands with Australia's security interests.

By committing the new government to the Quad and AUKUS without hesitation, he has signalled Labor's support for deepening US engagement in the regional task of protecting the peace, freedom and stability of the Indo-Pacific that is threatened by China's authoritarian geopolitical assertiveness.This is underlined by Foreign Minister Penny Wong's realist defence of the Albanese government's approach to managing China.

Labor critics such as former prime minister Paul Keating and former NSW premier Bob Carr have more or less accused the Albanese government of taking a hardline stance on China to obediently fall in to line with Washington.
This supposedly betrays the legacy of independent foreign policy and openness towards China pioneered by Labor prime minister Gough Whitlam.

Delivering the Gough Whitlam Oration to mark 50 years since the Whitlam government established diplomatic ties with Red China, Senator Wong says the critics are living "in a world that has long since passed".

There is no pretending there is an easy way back to a benign bilateral and mutually beneficial trade relationship, because the "China of today is not the same as the China of the 1970s, or even the 2000s", she says.
Instead, Australia must seek to co-operate where it can, disagree where it must, and always pursue its national interests.

That is broadly the right formula for a middle power commodity-exporting country at the foot of Asia, that has been made richer by the rise of modern China, but which must give first priority to protecting its sovereignty and security.

That is consistent with what should be Australia's overarching foreign policy objective: to encourage China to pull back behind the rules-based international order.Writing on this page today, Trade Minister Don Farrell commits Labor to supporting free and diversified trade as the foundation of Australian prosperity.
That includes backing Australia's continuing efforts to repair the multinational trade rule book and reform of the workings of the World Trade Organisation umpire.

Yet Labor also plans to water down and strip from future free trade agreements the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism, which promotes investment certainty by giving foreign investors the right to sue governments for policies that harm their businesses.

Particularly given that Australia is now a net capital exporter, removing protections against sovereign and political risk mostly exposes Australian offshore investment to arbitrary interference by trading partner governments.

While Senator Farrell says the changes would allow governments to "govern in the national interest", Australia's national interest lies in maintaining a rule-based system that provides confidence for trade and investment.

It might require governments to recognise the costs of changing the rules on investors when it suits - such as imposing gas price caps on LNG projects that have been underwritten by foreign investors.
This step towards greater government intervention in trade and investment is a concerning sign the Albanese government has not outgrown the prime minister's youthful anti-globalisation views.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: The foreign policy journey of Anthony Albanese from an opponent of George W. Bush's invasion of Iraq to a true believer in the US alliance is outlined on today's features pages by Sydney University professor of history James Curran and Elena Collinson of the Australia-China Institute. Early this century, the young firebrand from Labor's inner-city social activist wing held fashionable "progressive" opinions, including endorsing Naomi Klein-style anti-globalisation critiques of the "school of international order that sees no role for the nation state in trade or investment policies". Two decades on, the man who occupies The Lodge, and will represent Australia on the world stage during the next fortnight of back-to-back-to-back international summitry, supports maintaining and strengthening the critical security partnership with America. That positions Mr Albanese squarely in the bipartisan strategic consensus and the mainstream of Labor politics alongside its most electorally successful leader and ardent US alliance supporter, Bob Hawke. Foreign policy has not been Mr Albanese's political passion; hence he has come to office with relatively little "anti-US forces" baggage to declare.Yet, despite being inexperienced in international affairs, Mr Albanese so far has shown a safe pair of hands with Australia's security interests. By committing the new government to the Quad and AUKUS without hesitation, he has signalled Labor's support for deepening US engagement in the regional task of protecting the peace, freedom and stability of the Indo-Pacific that is threatened by China's authoritarian geopolitical assertiveness.This is underlined by Foreign Minister Penny Wong's realist defence of the Albanese government's approach to managing China. Labor critics such as former prime minister Paul Keating and former NSW premier Bob Carr have more or less accused the Albanese government of taking a hardline stance on China to obediently fall in to line with Washington. This supposedly betrays the legacy of independent foreign policy and openness towards China pioneered by Labor prime minister Gough Whitlam. Delivering the Gough Whitlam Oration to mark 50 years since the Whitlam government established diplomatic ties with Red China, Senator Wong says the critics are living "in a world that has long since passed". There is no pretending there is an easy way back to a benign bilateral and mutually beneficial trade relationship, because the "China of today is not the same as the China of the 1970s, or even the 2000s", she says. Instead, Australia must seek to co-operate where it can, disagree where it must, and always pursue its national interests. That is broadly the right formula for a middle power commodity-exporting country at the foot of Asia, that has been made richer by the rise of modern China, but which must give first priority to protecting its sovereignty and security. That is consistent with what should be Australia's overarching foreign policy objective: to encourage China to pull back behind the rules-based international order.Writing on this page today, Trade Minister Don Farrell commits Labor to supporting free and diversified trade as the foundation of Australian prosperity. That includes backing Australia's continuing efforts to repair the multinational trade rule book and reform of the workings of the World Trade Organisation umpire. Yet Labor also plans to water down and strip from future free trade agreements the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism, which promotes investment certainty by giving foreign investors the right to sue governments for policies that harm their businesses. Particularly given that Australia is now a net capital exporter, removing protections against sovereign and political risk mostly exposes Australian offshore investment to arbitrary interference by trading partner governments. It might require governments to recognise the costs of changing the rules on investors when it suits - such as imposing gas price caps on LNG projects that have been underwritten by foreign investors. This step towards greater government intervention in trade and investment is a concerning sign the Albanese government has not outgrown the prime minister's youthful anti-globalisation views.
